category_summary:
AI business and infrastructure dominated discussions. **Sam Altman** revealed **OpenAI** [added over $1B ARR](/?date=2026-01-23&category=social#item-1025dbc266bd) in a single month from APIs alone, highlighting the often-overlooked enterprise side. The **vLLM** creators [announced **Inferact**](/?date=2026-01-23&category=social#item-1159377fcffe) with a massive $150M seed led by **a16z**, signaling major investment in open-source inference infrastructure.

- **Shane Legg** (DeepMind co-founder) [declared "AGI is now on the horizon"](/?date=2026-01-23&category=social#item-3baa4524fe90) and is hiring economists to study post-AGI economics‚Äîa striking timeline signal
- **Anthropic** [revealed **Opus 4.5** beat](/?date=2026-01-23&category=social#item-898f600aad5b) their notoriously difficult engineering exam, forcing a redesign
- **Runway** CEO [reported 90%+](/?date=2026-01-23&category=social#item-b97adb1d420d) of participants couldn't distinguish **Gen-4.5** outputs from real video‚Äîa "tipping point" crossed
- **John Carmack** [shared deep technical analysis](/?date=2026-01-23&category=social#item-8aada2466a28) on flow-matching for value-based RL

**DeepMind** [announced **D4RT**](/?date=2026-01-23&category=social#item-266f0809b00f) for 4D video reconstruction (18x-300x faster). **Ethan Mollick** [highlighted research](/?date=2026-01-23&category=social#item-923da7dea9c8) showing humans increasingly using "ChatGPT-favorite words" in spoken language‚Äî"model collapse, except for humans." **Anthropic** [shipped the Tasks upgrade](/?date=2026-01-23&category=social#item-817d394e46f6) for longer Claude projects, while **OpenAI's Logan** [publicly praised](/?date=2026-01-23&category=social#item-89dd2024c4f9) **Gemini 3 Flash** as "highly underrated."

items.title: Today, we're proud to announce @inferact, a startup founded by creators and core maintainers of @vll...
items.content:
Today, we're proud to announce @inferact, a startup founded by creators and core maintainers of @vllm_project, the most popular open-source LLM inference engine.

Our mission is to grow vLLM as the world's AI inference engine and accelerate AI progress by making inference cheaper and faster.

The Challenge
Inference is not solved. It's getting harder.

Models grow larger. New architectures proliferate: mixture-of-experts, multimodal, agentic. Every breakthrough demands new infrastructure. Meanwhile, hardware fragments: more accelerators, more programming models, and more combinations to optimize.

The capability gap between models and the systems that serve them is widening. Left this way, the most capable models remain bottlenecked and with full scope of their capabilities accessible only to those who can build custom infrastructure. Close the gap, and we unlock new possibilities.

And the problem is growing. Inference is shifting from a fraction of compute to the majority: test-time compute, RL training loops, synthetic data.

We see a future where serving AI becomes effortless.

Today, deploying a frontier model at scale requires a dedicated infrastructure team. Tomorrow, it should be as simple as spinning up a serverless database. The complexity doesn't disappear; it gets absorbed into the infrastructure we're building.

Why Us
vLLM sits at the intersection of models and hardware: a position that took years to build.

When model vendors ship new architectures, they work with us to ensure day-zero support. When hardware vendors develop new silicon, they integrate with vLLM. When teams deploy at scale, they run vLLM, from frontier labs to hyperscalers to startups serving millions of users. Today, vLLM supports 500+ model architectures, runs on 200+ accelerator types, and powers inference at global scale. This ecosystem, built with 2,000+ contributors, is our foundation.

We've been stewards of this engine since its first commit. We know it inside out. We deployed it at frontier scale‚Äîin research and in production.

Open Source
vLLM was built in the open. That's not changing.

Inferact exists to supercharge vLLM adoption. The optimizations we develop flow back to the community. We plan to push vLLM's performance further, deepen support for emerging model architectures, and expand coverage across frontier hardware. The AI industry needs inference infrastructure that isn't locked behind proprietary walls.

Join Us
Through the open source community, we are fortunate to work with some of the best people we know. For @inferact, we're hiring engineers and researchers to work at the frontier of inference, where models meet hardware at scale. Come build with us.

We're fortunate to be supported by investors who share our vision, including @a16z and @lightspeedvp who led our $150M seed, as well as @sequoia, @AltimeterCap, @Redpoint, @ZhenFund, The House Fund, @strikervp, @LaudeVentures, and @databricks.

- @woosuk_k, @simon_mo_, @KaichaoYou, @rogerw0108, @istoica05 and the rest of the founding team

items.title:
#PaperADay 9
floq: Training Critics via Flow-Matching for Scaling Compute in Value-Based RL
https://...
items.content:
#PaperADay 9
floq: Training Critics via Flow-Matching for Scaling Compute in Value-Based RL
https://t.co/V4kCMfUkEK

In theory, value based reinforcement learning is a regression problem, which is most naturally addressed with an MSE loss. However, there are a bunch of subtle reasons why a neural network terminating in a single activation may not be an ideal value function approximator.

Most models today use a categorical value representation to mitigate some of the training issues, but the proposal here is to generate the categorical value with around 8 steps of a flow model, which plausibly makes it easier to represent complex mappings.

This kind of refinement-from-noise is appealing to me as a possible way to be sort of ‚Äúerror correcting‚Äù and combat the problem of catastrophic forgetting. If you learn something well, then train on something else for a few million optimizer steps, the odds are good that your original task performance will be almost back to random if you try it again. Hints of the original behavior remain, but covered in a lot of noise. Some kind of de-noising on the values would be a big help.

I‚Äôm not familiar with the benchmarks they use, but they appear to be comparing with a previous model, which may not be State Of The Art, and there is also some per-environment hyperparameter tuning. They target offline RL, optionally followed by a period of online fine-tuning, so there may be issues with the learning dynamics when going completely from scratch.

Their flow model is a 4-layer MLP, and I‚Äôm guessing they have a modestly sized explicit state. I‚Äôm not sure what the training dynamics would be if you had to co-learn a CNN feature extractor with the flow model.

They compare the flow model against both an 8x ensemble of value functions (going wide) and a ResNet with 8x the layers (going deep) and find that the flow model is notably superior.

The details of the ensemble could be important ‚Äì an ensemble of models trained on the same sequence of samples doesn‚Äôt help much in RL, but an ensemble trained with completely different IID samples can make a difference.

One of the key points about flow models is that they get supervision at every step, unlike a very deep traditional model that only gets supervision at the very end, which is backpropagated through all the layers. I wonder if you could train the deeper res-net with similar supervision at multiple interior points.

They presume to know ahead of time what the range of possible Q values are to set the range of the initial input noise, and it is a sensitive parameter on some of the benchmarks, which could be problematic.

Broad categorical value representation was essential; doing flow based on a scalar worked poorly.

The time input to the velocity network is a multi-channel fourier basis, using a scalar time also worked poorly.

I have been meaning to learn more about flow models, this has been a good prod.
items.author: @ID_AA_Carmack
items.summary: John Carmack's #PaperADay analysis of 'floq' paper on using flow-matching for value-based RL. Provides deep technical commentary on using flow models to generate categorical values in ~8 steps, discusses potential for error correction, compares against ensembles and deeper networks, and notes key implementation details like Fourier basis for time input.
items.reasoning: John Carmack is a legendary programmer whose technical analysis carries significant weight. This is a substantive, original deep-dive into cutting-edge RL research with practical insights about training dynamics, catastrophic forgetting, and flow models. High engagement (125 likes, 17K views).
items.summary_html: John Carmack's #PaperADay analysis of 'floq' paper on using flow-matching for value-based RL. Provides deep technical commentary on using flow models to generate categorical values in ~8 steps, discusses potential for error correction, compares against ensembles and deeper networks, and notes key implementation details like Fourier basis for time input.
items.content_html:
#PaperADay 9

floq: Training Critics via Flow-Matching for Scaling Compute in Value-Based RL

https://t.co/V4kCMfUkEK

In theory, value based reinforcement learning is a regression problem, which is most naturally addressed with an MSE loss. However, there are a bunch of subtle reasons why a neural network terminating in a single activation may not be an ideal value function approximator.

Most models today use a categorical value representation to mitigate some of the training issues, but the proposal here is to generate the categorical value with around 8 steps of a flow model, which plausibly makes it easier to represent complex mappings.

This kind of refinement-from-noise is appealing to me as a possible way to be sort of ‚Äúerror correcting‚Äù and combat the problem of catastrophic forgetting. If you learn something well, then train on something else for a few million optimizer steps, the odds are good that your original task performance will be almost back to random if you try it again. Hints of the original behavior remain, but covered in a lot of noise. Some kind of de-noising on the values would be a big help.

I‚Äôm not familiar with the benchmarks they use, but they appear to be comparing with a previous model, which may not be State Of The Art, and there is also some per-environment hyperparameter tuning. They target offline RL, optionally followed by a period of online fine-tuning, so there may be issues with the learning dynamics when going completely from scratch.

Their flow model is a 4-layer MLP, and I‚Äôm guessing they have a modestly sized explicit state. I‚Äôm not sure what the training dynamics would be if you had to co-learn a CNN feature extractor with the flow model.

They compare the flow model against both an 8x ensemble of value functions (going wide) and a ResNet with 8x the layers (going deep) and find that the flow model is notably superior.

The details of the ensemble could be important ‚Äì an ensemble of models trained on the same sequence of samples doesn‚Äôt help much in RL, but an ensemble trained with completely different IID samples can make a difference.

One of the key points about flow models is that they get supervision at every step, unlike a very deep traditional model that only gets supervision at the very end, which is backpropagated through all the layers. I wonder if you could train the deeper res-net with similar supervision at multiple interior points.

They presume to know ahead of time what the range of possible Q values are to set the range of the initial input noise, and it is a sensitive parameter on some of the benchmarks, which could be problematic.

Broad categorical value representation was essential; doing flow based on a scalar worked poorly.

The time input to the velocity network is a multi-channel fourier basis, using a scalar time also worked poorly.

I have been meaning to learn more about flow models, this has been a good prod.

items.title: GPT-5.2 Pro is good enough to check reproducibility & robustness of academic papers across many ...
items.content:
GPT-5.2 Pro is good enough to check reproducibility & robustness of academic papers across many fields (given the data, can you get the same results? are the statistics brittle?). At scale, this would have a big impact.

It can't do an independent replication with new data, yet.

items.title: We have been thinking a lot about what happens when generated and non-generated content are indistin...
items.content: We have been thinking a lot about what happens when generated and non-generated content are indistinguishable from one another. This is the first study to try to see if that threshold has been crossed. We have officially reached a tipping point: over 90% of participants could not reliably distinguish Gen-4.5 outputs from real video. We still have a lot to figure out collectively and culturally to make the best out of what‚Äôs coming ahead.
items.author: @c_valenzuelab
items.summary: Runway CEO reports study finding over 90% of participants couldn't reliably distinguish Gen-4.5 outputs from real video - 'tipping point' crossed
items.reasoning: Major milestone announcement: video generation reaching human indistinguishability. First study to test this threshold. Significant implications for content authenticity. High engagement (8.5K views)

This is the first study to try to see if that threshold has been crossed. We have officially reached a tipping point: over 90% of participants could not reliably distinguish Gen-4.5 outputs from real video. We still have a lot to figure out collectively and culturally to make the best out of what‚Äôs coming ahead.

Yesterday, I spoke with a developer who stopped contributing to open-source projects.

10+ years doing this, and now he's done.

"Why should I spend my weekends building something that will just become training data for the next model?"

I don't like where this is going.

items.title: After visiting quite a few robotics companies here in USA and talking with many over in China, @elon...
items.content:
After visiting quite a few robotics companies here in USA and talking with many over in China, @elonmusk's predictions sound reasonable, albeit everyone says that it will take five years for a generalized robot that can do everything we expect. But there are many people and businesses that will buy an early robot that can't do everything, been studying them too (one reason why I was able to write eight books about the future is that I got into people's homes all over the world to do consumer research thanks to having a famous Silicon Valley blog for decades). 

But we all know Elon time is ahead of human time by quite a bit. His statements this morning remind me of 2018 when he said autonomous vehicles are just around the corner. Now eight years later that statement is coming true. I bought it knowing that it would take years (spent $6,000 on FSD way back then, and am happy I did so, my robot has driven me all over America).

The cynics will look at cost and say "no way will he sell millions of robots." The typical American home doesn't have any device in it that costs more than $2,000. 

Which gets me back to how do you reduce the cost to that level?

Rent it. 

Most American homes don't actually have that much work for a robot. For the last eight years I've been running my household with now teenage kids at home. The unenjoyable part of home life is stuff like laundry. Now that my kids are teenagers they are like cheap robots, we have them doing chores like dishes and laundry.

I'm still convinced the first 20 million won't be bought by home owners anyway. Other than rich people who want to show off. "Hey Optimus get my friends a beer."

On the other hand there are plenty who can afford a $20,000 a robot to help out with labor shortages. Even if they can only do a few specific tasks.

Businesses. Factories. Machine shops. Places like my brother's bar. Could he buy one to do dishes or help out behind the scenes with cooking, or moving around inventory (kegs of beer are heavy). 

But home robots? 

In a perfect world I'd buy one to do my laundry, cleaning, but then it would sit unused for hours every week unless it gets really capable to do food preparation (I already have a robot from @eatwithposha to do the cooking part). It could definitely do setting of the table by 2029, and a lot of these tasks. But it still would be unused for many hours in a day. 

What if it could be rented to my neighbors to do simple tasks for them too? 

Then the cost comes down quite a bit. A $20,000 robot that just does laundry could serve two homes a day. That's 14 homes. 

It still is fairly expensive. Is $100 a week for doing laundry and some cleaning up worth it? 

For upper middle class city dwellers? Maybe.

But this is why I am studying people with bad knees. 

They have a completely different value proposition than typical parents who are working in some executive job. And in America alone there are 60 million people with bad knees.

They are suffering every time they stand. 

Then the value proposition is "will I spend $100 a week to suffer less?"

The answer to that is a much stronger yes. 

I'm rambling, but to wrap this up, Elon and others will find customers to buy his robot in a limited form until the world models get good enough for it to be cost reduced and generalized. And safe to become a mainstream product that even more than five percent of homes own.

I doubt that the average home will have one before 2035, but if you have parents with bad knees, or a business owner who can't get enough good help to do some menial tasks in a machine shop, or working at, say, a laundromat or other business? Yeah, there is demand there. 

One thing I learned by visiting @maticrobots factory where they make a few hundred a week? Manufacturing is hard, very hard. Especially starting a factory up from scratch. That is even true for Elon, who has a half dozen factories that make things.

Early customers are key to getting manufacturing up to scale, I learned. 

And finding early customers is all about putting a dream out there. Which is what Elon has been doing for years. Remember the dancing human dressed up as a humanoid?

I find the robot industry so interesting because it is so hard to introduce a major new product to people who don't already own such a product. 

And this one is one of the most complex products ever developed by human beings. 

That said, I love the dream, and certainly will be amongst those that talk about it, and other companies (I have a list here on X of all of them), that bring interesting new robots out to people.

Now back to other innovation, later today will have a video of an entrepreneur that's using blockchain technologies to bring a new kind of AI-first store to all of us.

items.title: It still feels a little unreal to look back at how far @vllm_project has come. What started as a sma...
items.content:
It still feels a little unreal to look back at how far @vllm_project has come. What started as a small research project that Zhuohan and I launched ended up receiving so much love and connecting me with people who are now some of my closest friends. In so many ways, I already feel incredibly lucky for what this journey has given me.

To be honest, my path with vLLM hasn‚Äôt been perfectly straight. Over the past three years, my passion dipped at times, and I did spend my energy exploring things I thought were more interesting than vLLM and inference. vLLM is what it is today because of the community, and I‚Äôm truly grateful for their commitment.

My view on inference also evolved a lot along the way. What once felt mostly ‚Äúsolved‚Äù turned out to be far from it. The rapid pace of new models, increasingly complex architectures, diverse hardware setups, and agents have made inference genuinely hard. The need for strong inference infrastructure has only kept growing, and it became clear just how much important work remains.

Somewhere along that journey, I realized how special this work really is and how uniquely positioned vLLM is. Now, I‚Äôm committed to pushing it all the way. With that, I started @inferact with @simon_mo_, @KaichaoYou, @rogerw0108, @istoica05, and amazing founding team from both inside and outside the vLLM community. I‚Äôm deeply grateful to our investors, including @a16z and @lightspeedvp, for believing in us and giving us this opportunity.

Excited for this next chapter, and looking forward to sharing more soon.

items.summary: vLLM co-creator woosuk_k shares personal reflection on project's evolution, announces commitment to Inferact. Notes inference is getting harder with larger models, new architectures (MoE, multimodal, agentic), and hardware fragmentation.

To be honest, my path with vLLM hasn‚Äôt been perfectly straight. Over the past three years, my passion dipped at times, and I did spend my energy exploring things I thought were more interesting than vLLM and inference. vLLM is what it is today because of the community, and I‚Äôm truly grateful for their commitment.

My view on inference also evolved a lot along the way. What once felt mostly ‚Äúsolved‚Äù turned out to be far from it. The rapid pace of new models, increasingly complex architectures, diverse hardware setups, and agents have made inference genuinely hard. The need for strong inference infrastructure has only kept growing, and it became clear just how much important work remains.

Somewhere along that journey, I realized how special this work really is and how uniquely positioned vLLM is. Now, I‚Äôm committed to pushing it all the way. With that, I started @inferact with @simon_mo_, @KaichaoYou, @rogerw0108, @istoica05, and amazing founding team from both inside and outside the vLLM community. I‚Äôm deeply grateful to our investors, including @a16z and @lightspeedvp, for believing in us and giving us this opportunity.

Excited for this next chapter, and looking forward to sharing more soon.

items.title: there are two ways of "automating the coordination/workflow layer" within the enterprise. one way ba...
items.content:
there are two ways of "automating the coordination/workflow layer" within the enterprise. one way basically already exists and the other is a stretch goal for 2026

1. translate an SOP into a repetitive workflow. for instance, invoice processing, claims processing, policy compliance. a lot of rote, routine work typically performed by humans 

we can do this today, as long as you have a core modules (e.g. llamaparse for OCR) along with workflow orchestration

this can also be shared across teams and operate deterministically

2. long-running, dynamic agents that can dynamically listen to all knowledge shared within the organization and solve any task.

this is the goal for 2026. no more need to write SOPs in the first place

items.title: I've been covering autonomous vehicles for decades now (had the first ride in Mercedes autonomous ve...
items.content:
I've been covering autonomous vehicles for decades now (had the first ride in Mercedes autonomous vehicle, and the first video of a Waymo on a freeway here in Silicon Valley).

Waymo beat Tesla by three years. Some of my friends take them to work every day, including the guy who runs @FactoryAI in San Francisco. 

But being first rarely matters in this world. Google was the 17th search engine. iPhone wasn't the first smart phone. 

Microsoft Word wasn't the first word processor.

Instagram wasn't the first photo app. 

Uber wasn't the first transportation as a service company. 

AirBnb wasn't the first place to rent a room. 

Amazon wasn't the first book store.

Now the game changes to "who has the best experience?"

Tesla is a long way from beating Uber or taxis around the world.

That said, there are so many skeptics about Tesla's self driving efforts. 

I'm not one of them. I see how it'll win a big share of the Robotaxi markets around the world even as Chinese companies are coming on strong.

Been a Tesla investor since 2018 and I'm not selling.

items.title: GPT-5.2 Pro is good enough to check reproducibility & robustness of academic papers across many fiel...
items.content:
GPT-5.2 Pro is good enough to check reproducibility & robustness of academic papers across many fields (given the data, can you get the same results? are the statistics brittle?). I wouldn't trust it to automate decisions, but to flag them.

It can't do an independent replication with new data, yet.

items.title: New course: Gemini CLI: Code & Create with an Open-Source Agent, built with @googlecloudtech/@gemini...
items.content:
New course: Gemini CLI: Code & Create with an Open-Source Agent, built with @googlecloudtech/@geminicli and taught by @JackWoth98.

Agentic coding assistants like Gemini CLI are transforming how developers work. This short course teaches you to use Google's open-source agent to coordinate local tools and cloud services for coding and non-coding workflows.

Gemini CLI works from your terminal, so it works with your local files and development tools. You can also connect it to services through MCP. Then provide high-level instructions, and it autonomously plans and executes complex workflows.

Skills you'll gain:
- Build website features and automate code reviews with GitHub ActionsCreate data dashboards that combine local files with cloud data sources
- Use MCP servers and extensions to orchestrate workflows across GitHub, Canva, and Google Workspace
- Generate social media content from multimedia files like conference recordings

I particularly appreciate that Gemini CLI is open-source. You can see exactly how it works, read the prompts it uses, and understand its architecture. The community has contributed thousands of pull requests. Since Gemini 3‚Äôs release I've found Gemini CLI highly capable - this is a tool worth having in your toolbox!

Whether you're prototyping applications, automating workflows, or working with multimedia content, join to learn to delegate complex tasks and build faster: https://t.co/m3J7kwQpxC

items.title:
‚ú® It's been almost a year since the plane game

So I thought I'd try see if the new AI models can im...
items.content:
‚ú® It's been almost a year since the plane game

So I thought I'd try see if the new AI models can improve https://t.co/UVJczDtp9x where I got stuck at some point last year

One thing in particular was the flight model, like how it moved in the sky wasn't very realistic and when I tried to improve that a year ago, all the AI models failed, it was too complex

I tried it now and it actually worked in 2 prompts, so it almost one-shotted a flight model that's more realistic with built-in stalling, the first was like "change it to a realistic flight model" and the second question was "okay but I can't take off" and then it fixed that and I took off!

Another thing I did now is connect Claude Code with Chrome directly (I'll try it on Cursor later too with the new built-in browser) and asked it to spin up a local Nginx server hosting the plaen game, so it can now refresh the page and just check bugs and improve much faster than I could by myself

There's a lot of stuff I want to improve here and the plane game is a good "acid test" for me to check how far the AI models have come (as the Vibe Jam 2026 is that I will announce soon too!)
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio demonstrates using Claude Code to improve a plane game, showing AI models can now one-shot realistic flight physics that failed last year. Also connected Claude Code to Chrome for automated testing/improvement loops.
items.reasoning: Practical demonstration of AI capability improvements over past year. Interesting workflow innovation connecting coding AI to browser testing.

items.content_html:
‚ú® It's been almost a year since the plane game

So I thought I'd try see if the new AI models can improve https://t.co/UVJczDtp9x where I got stuck at some point last year

One thing in particular was the flight model, like how it moved in the sky wasn't very realistic and when I tried to improve that a year ago, all the AI models failed, it was too complex

I tried it now and it actually worked in 2 prompts, so it almost one-shotted a flight model that's more realistic with built-in stalling, the first was like "change it to a realistic flight model" and the second question was "okay but I can't take off" and then it fixed that and I took off!

Another thing I did now is connect Claude Code with Chrome directly (I'll try it on Cursor later too with the new built-in browser) and asked it to spin up a local Nginx server hosting the plaen game, so it can now refresh the page and just check bugs and improve much faster than I could by myself

There's a lot of stuff I want to improve here and the plane game is a good "acid test" for me to check how far the AI models have come (as the Vibe Jam 2026 is that I will announce soon too!)

items.title:
we need an agents .md for everything

coding agents got better when we collectively decided on a des...
items.content:
we need an agents .md for everything

coding agents got better when we collectively decided on a design pattern: point the coding agent to a single md file

they got even better when we started organizing multiple md files, stemming from our core md file as an entry point

this isn't necessarily a new idea, as there has been ton of focus on improving "context" for agents this past year

what i haven't seen outside of coding though, is unified language around how to organize context. it's a pretty opinionated space, so we'll see lots of patterns

but i think the idea of having a single entry point for "core context" is a helpful concept for everyone, and simple enough to build on top of in an opinionated matter

hence, we need an agents .md for everything

items.summary: Yohei Nakajima argues for 'agents.md for everything' - a unified design pattern using single .md file entry points for agent context, building on success in coding agents

items.title:
Okay, I got Claude Code to actually fly my plane now

It controls the keys via Chrome by running it ...
items.content:
Okay, I got Claude Code to actually fly my plane now

It controls the keys via Chrome by running it with `claude --chrome`

There is some issue with the lift vs gravity formula though so it takes a lot of speed to take off, but it's really cool to see it control and fly the plane

This means it can code the game and then play it to check in a loop to theoretically improve it without my help (haven't gotten there though)

I run it like this btw:

`IS_SANDBOX=1 claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --chrome`

(Run at your own risk)

There is some issue with the lift vs gravity formula though so it takes a lot of speed to take off, but it's really cool to see it control and fly the plane

This means it can code the game and then play it to check in a loop to theoretically improve it without my help (haven't gotten there though)

I run it like this btw:

`IS_SANDBOX=1 claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --chrome`

(Run at your own risk)

items.title:
We have completely revamped our LlamaCloud APIs around document parsing.

1Ô∏è‚É£ There is now full Type...
items.content:
We have completely revamped our LlamaCloud APIs around document parsing.

1Ô∏è‚É£ There is now full Typescript support at 1:1 parity with our Python package.

2Ô∏è‚É£ We have massively simplified our output configuration, so that you can choose how to configure input document types, how you want to format the outputs, and the core OCR processing loop. 

3Ô∏è‚É£ This standardizes APIs for all new capabilities going forward, including our Split API. 

All of this is under our new `llama-cloud` SDKs under our "v2" APIs. 

Our existing `llama-cloud-services` SDK (25M+ monthly downloads) will still be around for the next few months, but our new APIs under `llama-cloud` will be the recommended path forward.

Announcement: https://t.co/lIU5bD73UT

Migration guide: https://t.co/wQm2mY6A2B

Python/TS `llama-cloud` package: 
https://t.co/Xp0dvBTkcQ
https://t.co/5QE91ICBW5

items.summary: Jerry Liu announces complete LlamaCloud API revamp: full TypeScript support at parity with Python, simplified output configuration, standardized APIs for new capabilities including Split API.

3Ô∏è‚É£ This standardizes APIs for all new capabilities going forward, including our Split API.

All of this is under our new `llama-cloud` SDKs under our "v2" APIs.

Our existing `llama-cloud-services` SDK (25M+ monthly downloads) will still be around for the next few months, but our new APIs under `llama-cloud` will be the recommended path forward.

items.title: When asking Claude to implement a serious change involving modifying too many files, it can die befo...
items.content:
When asking Claude to implement a serious change involving modifying too many files, it can die before it completes. A trick is to ask it to split the work into stages and put the stages in order of importance, from foundational changes to features.

Once it lists the stages, ask it to implement Stage 1 only and provide updated files. Integrate these files and ask it to proceed to Stage 2, etc.

This way, even if it dies in the middle, you can copy the initial list of stages and start a new session with Claude by asking it to verify whether the stages that were supposed to be implemented are complete and, if yes, proceed to the next unimplemented stage.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov shares practical tip for working with Claude on large changes: split work into stages ordered by importance, allowing recovery if session dies.
items.reasoning: Practical coding tip for Claude users with real utility. Good engagement for a how-to post.
items.summary_html: Burkov shares practical tip for working with Claude on large changes: split work into stages ordered by importance, allowing recovery if session dies.
items.content_html:
When asking Claude to implement a serious change involving modifying too many files, it can die before it completes. A trick is to ask it to split the work into stages and put the stages in order of importance, from foundational changes to features.

Once it lists the stages, ask it to implement Stage 1 only and provide updated files. Integrate these files and ask it to proceed to Stage 2, etc.

This way, even if it dies in the middle, you can copy the initial list of stages and start a new session with Claude by asking it to verify whether the stages that were supposed to be implemented are complete and, if yes, proceed to the next unimplemented stage.

Weaviate + StackAI just released a free technical gui...
items.content:
95% of enterprise AI pilots failed last year.

Weaviate + StackAI just released a free technical guide on building RAG agents for production.

‚Ä¢ It covers chunking strategies, hybrid search, and re-ranking
‚Ä¢ Security-first design considerations (SSO, RBAC, multi-tenancy)
‚Ä¢ Real use cases with workflow and architecture diagrams

Worth reading if you're still trying to build an AI agent that actually works.

items.title: We don't YOLO on top of microcode. There's many layers of increasingly deep abstraction on top of it...
items.content:
We don't YOLO on top of microcode. There's many layers of increasingly deep abstraction on top of it, each depending on the layer below. Each is carefully tested and has well defined boundaries.

That's why you only normally need understand the code at the layer you're using.
items.author: @jeremyphoward
items.summary: Jeremy Howard explains software abstraction layers - we don't 'YOLO' on microcode; careful testing and boundaries at each layer allow working at one abstraction level
items.reasoning: Fast.ai founder making important point about software reliability and abstraction relevant to AI-generated code debates. Good engagement (9K views)

D4RT can continuously understand what's moving while running 18x‚Äì300x faster than previous methods - processing a 1-minute video in roughly 5 seconds on a single TPU chip.

items.title:
@Dan_Jeffries1 I hear you, but here is my concern:

When cars replaced horses, many jobs disappeared...
items.content:
@Dan_Jeffries1 I hear you, but here is my concern:

When cars replaced horses, many jobs disappeared, and a bunch of new car-related jobs were created.

But stable boys didn't become car mechanics. People can't just "transition" to the new thing.

There will be something new, for sure, but I don't know whether the people being displaced today will be the ones who will benefit from it.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago discusses AI job displacement, arguing that displaced workers often can't transition to new roles (stable boys didn't become car mechanics analogy).
items.reasoning: Thoughtful commentary on AI's economic impact with good analogy. Part of important discourse.

items.title:
Why do so many AI tools work brilliantly in demos but fail to scale in production?

At #CES, John St...
items.content:
Why do so many AI tools work brilliantly in demos but fail to scale in production?

At #CES, John Stevenson, CPO at @PTC, gave me the answer: "There are a lot of AI tools that are enterprise-ready, but they need to be deployed within an enterprise framework."

Your governance, security, and data strategy are the blockers.

His advice: Advise ‚Üí Assist ‚Üí Automate
Start with AI answering questions. Then automate with humans in control. Only deploy full agents when outcomes are proven and verifiable.

The gap between pilot and production is organizational.

Watch our conversation: https://t.co/ZWAmMFPd1V

#EnterpriseAI #AIStrategy #CES2026
items.author: @YuHelenYu
items.summary: Helen Yu shares CES interview with PTC CPO John Stevenson about why AI tools fail to scale from demos to production. Key insight: governance, security, and data strategy are blockers. Recommends 'Advise ‚Üí Assist ‚Üí Automate' framework.
items.reasoning: Practical enterprise AI adoption framework from a CPO at a major company. The staged approach (Advise ‚Üí Assist ‚Üí Automate) offers actionable guidance for organizations deploying AI.

items.title: D4RT encodes input videos into a compressed version, then processes and queries the data using a lig...
items.content:
D4RT encodes input videos into a compressed version, then processes and queries the data using a lightweight decoder in parallel.

This makes it extremely fast and scalable - whether to track just a few points, or to reconstruct an entire scene.  üñºÔ∏è

items.title: We have amazing OCR tech within LlamaParse, and lots of options to configure the parsed outputs acco...
items.content:
We have amazing OCR tech within LlamaParse, and lots of options to configure the parsed outputs according to your specifications - almost too many options! 

We spent a lot of time thoughtfully simplifying the API so that you still get amazing parsing out of the box, with just the right number of toggles that make sense to configure the outputs.

items.title: @jefferinc Even Waymo's own market research shows that cost is the #1 reason why people will choose ...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer analyzes autonomous vehicle market dynamics - cost and availability as key factors between Waymo, Uber, Lyft, Tesla. Expresses continued Tesla investment confidence
items.reasoning: Market analysis from tech commentator with industry access. Substantive points about robotaxi competition but in reply format with limited engagement
items.summary_html: Scobleizer analyzes autonomous vehicle market dynamics - cost and availability as key factors between Waymo, Uber, Lyft, Tesla. Expresses continued Tesla investment confidence
items.content_html:
@jefferinc Even Waymo's own market research shows that cost is the #1 reason why people will choose between Uber, Lyft, Taxis, and Tesla and Waymo itself.

But availability is high too. Who can get a better fleet? That can go further and visit more things? Right now Uber is the leader there -- by far.

Will be interesting to watch as Tesla grows to see if it can change the game. I believe it can, which is why I'm not selling my investment.

items.title: @JacobKinge I was at a Silicon Valley robotics meetup tonight with very high-end entrepreneurs and o...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer pushes back on 'Silicon Valley insider' narratives, noting that at a high-end robotics meetup, people talked about making robots to help people rather than concerning schemes
items.reasoning: High engagement (34K views, 150 likes). Provides grounded perspective on what Silicon Valley robotics community actually discusses. Counter-narrative to fear-based discourse.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer pushes back on 'Silicon Valley insider' narratives, noting that at a high-end robotics meetup, people talked about making robots to help people rather than concerning schemes
items.content_html:
@JacobKinge I was at a Silicon Valley robotics meetup tonight with very high-end entrepreneurs and others in the ecosystem. I talked to many of them, and we didn't talk about this at all.

I don't know where you get this "Silicon Valley insider" stuff. I like playing insider Silicon Valley games too, but I have talked to many insiders and nobody talks like this. We're talking about how to make robots to help people.

I don't know what meetings you're going to.

items.title: Lots of backwork I couldn't do last year cause I hit the limit AI models intelligence and also conte...
items.content:
Lots of backwork I couldn't do last year cause I hit the limit AI models intelligence and also context length that I fixed today

- Rebuild the entire plane physics flight model, it now operates more close to a real plane
- New height system: Sea level at 0, ground at 10 (was hardcoded 35/36)
- Flight deck ship that's eleveated
- Beach has depth: No longer paper-thin, fills gap between ground and sea
- Plane shadows: Sharp shadows from plane onto runway, carrier deck, beach & ocean
- Cessna landing gear: Added white diagonal struts connecting wheels to fuselage, toggleable with G
- Radar shows runways: Runway and carrier now visible as white markers on minimap
- Less camera zoom: Reduced FOV increase at high speeds

It seems I can improve it a lot now with ease

More features coming :D

items.title: @BenjaminDEKR Yeah, and the real problem is that we are the product. And the weights are adjusted to...
items.content:
@BenjaminDEKR Yeah, and the real problem is that we are the product. And the weights are adjusted to make the product appeal to more people. 

The only way around this is to use lists and X Pro, so you can see everything in real time with no algorithmic filtering. 

But that won't help you get suggested to be followed. That won't help you get reach. 

And the algorithm is constantly changing. Because AI is constantly learning now. 

So the game is out of our hands.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer explains X/Twitter algorithm dynamics - we are the product, weights adjust to maximize appeal, AI constantly learning means algorithm constantly changing, suggests using lists and X Pro for unfiltered content
items.reasoning: Insightful meta-commentary on social media AI systems and how to work around algorithmic filtering. Practical advice included
items.summary_html: Scobleizer explains X/Twitter algorithm dynamics - we are the product, weights adjust to maximize appeal, AI constantly learning means algorithm constantly changing, suggests using lists and X Pro for unfiltered content
items.content_html:
@BenjaminDEKR Yeah, and the real problem is that we are the product. And the weights are adjusted to make the product appeal to more people.

The only way around this is to use lists and X Pro, so you can see everything in real time with no algorithmic filtering.

But that won't help you get suggested to be followed. That won't help you get reach.

And the algorithm is constantly changing. Because AI is constantly learning now.

So the game is out of our hands.

items.title:
@shyamvaran @Uber @lyft @Tesla @Waymo Yeah, the threat will come over next few years. 

In San Franc...
items.content:
@shyamvaran @Uber @lyft @Tesla @Waymo Yeah, the threat will come over next few years. 

In San Francisco they already are feeling a drain as customers leave human driven cars to go to Waymos. 

Waymo customers tell me over and over again they would never use Uber or Lyft if they had a choice. Often they don't have a choice, like going to the airport, but those problems will go away quickly.

In three years we will be in a different world. 

And Tesla and Waymo will be able to greatly underprice any human driven vehicle soon. 

They should be worried, if they look at three years from now. 

If they are only looking at today, I can see why they aren't worried.

Plus Uber is working hard on finding other things for them to do. 

The next three years will see a ton of change.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer predicts autonomous vehicles will significantly disrupt Uber/Lyft within 3 years. Notes SF Waymo customers say they'd never use human-driven rideshare again if given choice. Tesla and Waymo will undercut human drivers on price.
items.reasoning: Forward-looking analysis on autonomous vehicle market disruption based on claimed customer research. Relevant market perspective but speculative.

@shyamvaran @Uber @lyft @Tesla @Waymo Yeah, the threat will come over next few years.

In San Francisco they already are feeling a drain as customers leave human driven cars to go to Waymos.

Waymo customers tell me over and over again they would never use Uber or Lyft if they had a choice. Often they don't have a choice, like going to the airport, but those problems will go away quickly.

In three years we will be in a different world.

And Tesla and Waymo will be able to greatly underprice any human driven vehicle soon.

They should be worried, if they look at three years from now.

If they are only looking at today, I can see why they aren't worried.

Plus Uber is working hard on finding other things for them to do.

The next three years will see a ton of change.

items.title: I wouldn't trust an AI model to definitively point out a reproduction or robustness problem, its not...
items.content:
I wouldn't trust an AI model to definitively point out a reproduction or robustness problem, its not good enough for that yet, but it does a good job flagging issues for potential review.

Best approach is for authors to use it to double check their work and get feedback.

items.title:
@pbeisel Love your thinking.

To me it comes down to:

Capabilities.
Price.
Brand.
Distribution.

It...
items.content:
@pbeisel Love your thinking.

To me it comes down to:

Capabilities.
Price.
Brand.
Distribution.

It's hard to see a Western company that can threaten Tesla on any of these. I've been visiting a ton of robot companies who are trying, and have a list here on X of everyone in robotics. There are so many potential customers that there will be room for a few different approaches, from heavier more industrial robots working in factories, to specialized robots working with elderly, to a more generalized approach, to others (delivery robots, etc, from Amazon). 

Now the Chinese? They can price us into the ground, and innovate a lot faster to find new customer needs and serve them. Tesla is the one Western company with a factory in China, at least so far. So it has a good look at where the competition is coming from there too.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer analyzes Tesla's competitive position in robotics, identifying key factors: capabilities, price, brand, distribution. Notes Chinese competitors can 'price us into the ground' and innovate faster.
items.reasoning: Market analysis of robotics competition between Tesla and Chinese companies. Identifies competitive dynamics and Tesla's advantage through China factory presence.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer analyzes Tesla's competitive position in robotics, identifying key factors: capabilities, price, brand, distribution. Notes Chinese competitors can 'price us into the ground' and innovate faster.
items.content_html:
@pbeisel Love your thinking.

To me it comes down to:

Capabilities.

Price.

Brand.

Distribution.

It's hard to see a Western company that can threaten Tesla on any of these. I've been visiting a ton of robot companies who are trying, and have a list here on X of everyone in robotics. There are so many potential customers that there will be room for a few different approaches, from heavier more industrial robots working in factories, to specialized robots working with elderly, to a more generalized approach, to others (delivery robots, etc, from Amazon).

Now the Chinese? They can price us into the ground, and innovate a lot faster to find new customer needs and serve them. Tesla is the one Western company with a factory in China, at least so far. So it has a good look at where the competition is coming from there too.

items.title: finally starting to see some longer solutions in KISS (prompting game), after disabling emojis and s...
items.content:
finally starting to see some longer solutions in KISS (prompting game), after disabling emojis and special characters.

solutions still aren't quite like in the taboo game where you have to speak the hints, there are still a lot of acryonym/hacky solutions which isn't necessarily bad.

just trying to experiment with new game ideas that revolve around "prompting"

for example yesterday, to get the AI to correctly guess "once in a blue moon", the winning solutions (using few characters as possible were):

- oncNLua
- onc iabm
- occursOne
- 1ce a blue
- Onc InBuMn

today's puzzle is "kick the bucket"

play at https://t.co/NLzL37QeC9

items.title: @ChunkOfTheStars In Vegas you are missing the tunnels that Elon is building. This gives Elon a legal...
items.content:
@ChunkOfTheStars In Vegas you are missing the tunnels that Elon is building. This gives Elon a legal monopoly coming in 2028. You'll be able to go from the airport to the front door of the convention center. This stop is the convention center, where I saw thousands of people taking rides in the tunnels.

Only Tesla will be allowed in the tunnels, and this will be a far superior way to get around Las Vegas than any other. It is a far faster and far better experience, and it will be very cool once autonomous driving comes to the tunnels (which should happen this year).
items.author: @Scobleizer

items.title: "Watching this video isn't just educational; it's transformative for anyone interested in the future...
items.content:
"Watching this video isn't just educational; it's transformative for anyone interested in the future of business. 

Viewers will emerge with a nuanced understanding of how Web 3.0 and AI intersect to create inclusive, efficient systems‚Äîreducing barriers, cutting costs, and fostering innovation. For SMEs, it's a blueprint for competing with giants; for tech professionals, it's a masterclass in practical implementation. 

Ultimately, the key lesson is optimism: these technologies aren't distant dreams but accessible tools reshaping commerce today. If you're building or investing in the next wave of digital businesses, this interview provides the knowledge to stay ahead."

items.title: @solametrics @DhalgrenMarquis Well, a car should be able to drive forward just by looking backward. ...
items.content:
@solametrics @DhalgrenMarquis Well, a car should be able to drive forward just by looking backward. It knows where the road is (especially if you are on a straight road). 

The only problem then is seeing someone that it might hit. Which most of the time won't be a problem, which is why most of the time humans can look at their phones for a few seconds and not the road and still not crash. It's when something unexpected happens up ahead that humans crash. 

Like I said, AI can take a variety of approaches to getting people safely to the side of the road to wait 15 minutes until the sun goes down. 

And that's if it remains a problem at all. Like I said, mine has driven into the sun dozens of times now without having a problem. 

The main problem here is we don't have the data beyond anecdotal evidence. Which is why it'll be interesting to see further scaling and what kinds of problems show up after Robotaxi gets further turned on.

items.title: @solametrics @DhalgrenMarquis Even in Sun it should be able to pull over. There are plenty of workin...
items.content:
@solametrics @DhalgrenMarquis Even in Sun it should be able to pull over. There are plenty of working cameras not aimed at sun to even make a best guess. Which is how humans drive when blinded by the sun too. 

Like I said, it'll be interesting to see how Tesla solves this problem and what their own data is showing. The lawyers won't let it on the road if it causes accidents. Too many potential lawsuits and PR problems.

items.title: @solametrics I use cameras all the time to stare at the sun. I see lots of ways that AI can improve ...
items.content:
@solametrics I use cameras all the time to stare at the sun. I see lots of ways that AI can improve problems with glare. 

But another way, at least in places that have lots of Teslas? Join them together to increase numbers of cameras that can see the environment around them. That's coming someday soon. The robot people at other companies say that the researchers are working on just that, and I imagine Tesla will continue using SOTA approaches to make their robots more capable and safer. 

But a lot of this is wishful thinking. Today. Like I said, will be interesting to see the data and see how Tesla improves this over time. 

I can see where Robotaxi first starts with only Cybercab for Robotaxi as it grows in scale. That will have better cameras, more compute (next year), and devices like what was detailed in patents from Tesla.

If there is a human in the car, I can see it'll warn that light conditions don't support humanless driving so you gotta be ready to take over (in owned cars). 

Like I said, will be interesting to see how Tesla solves this problem.

items.title:
@EdHill63367243 Several reasons:

The traditional automakers (or oil/gas sellers) are trying to slow...
items.content:
@EdHill63367243 Several reasons:

The traditional automakers (or oil/gas sellers) are trying to slow down Tesla to give them chance to catch up, or, to further bleed the turnip of selling cars and keeping people addicted to buying gas.

They pay people to cause FUD.

Another big reason is Elon's involvement in politics. Lots of people hate him for that. 

Another reason is ignorance. Many of the naysayers don't have a Tesla and have no idea how fast it is improving. 

Fear of change, resistance, is another one.

items.summary_html: Scobleizer discusses Tesla patent for new camera filter to help with low-sun conditions, mentions remote human takeover for Robotaxi and possible safety modes for FSD.
items.content_html:
@solametrics Well, they do know it's a problem. A recent patent showed a new kind of filter that would greatly help the cameras in a low-sun system.

For Robotaxi I can see a human will take over remotely in such a situation. But for FSD I can see that it will sense low-sun situations and turn off full autonomy and force the human to pay attention.

Will be interesting to see how it continues to chew on this problem.

items.title: How is Web 3.0 (blockchain and decentralized Web) and AI mixing to make new kinds of businesses poss...
items.content:
How is Web 3.0 (blockchain and decentralized Web) and AI mixing to make new kinds of businesses possible? 

I sat down with the founders of @BasaltHQ to learn about its new store (Shopify competitor) that uses blockchain-based cryptocurrencies to reduce the cost of selling items (credit cards cost every seller about 3%, plus billions of people around the world don't have credit cards so you can't sell to them).
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer interviews BasaltHQ founders about Web 3.0/blockchain + AI convergence for e-commerce, positioning as Shopify competitor using crypto to reduce transaction costs.
items.reasoning: Interview coverage of Web3+AI intersection for business models. Promotional but addresses real use case of reducing payment friction.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer interviews BasaltHQ founders about Web 3.0/blockchain + AI convergence for e-commerce, positioning as Shopify competitor using crypto to reduce transaction costs.
items.content_html:
How is Web 3.0 (blockchain and decentralized Web) and AI mixing to make new kinds of businesses possible?

I sat down with the founders of @BasaltHQ to learn about its new store (Shopify competitor) that uses blockchain-based cryptocurrencies to reduce the cost of selling items (credit cards cost every seller about 3%, plus billions of people around the world don't have credit cards so you can't sell to them).

items.title:
GigEagle  

This month, the Defense Department's Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Office ha...
items.content:
GigEagle  

This month, the Defense Department's Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Office has invested over $5 million in GigEagle's AI Platform for Military, a Joint talent marketplace.  "Collaborating at the enterprise level marks a pivotal advancement in leveraging and scaling GigEagle's innovative technology for the DoD's digital workforce," stated Air Force Brig. Gen. Michael T. McGinley, director of GigEagle and the Agile Talent for AI. By joining forces, we are revolutionizing how the Department effectively discovers and deploys the right talent to tackle emerging challenges.

items.title: @echetus "The US should arm Putin to destroy the democracies of Europe" is an increasingly popular i...
items.content: @echetus "The US should arm Putin to destroy the democracies of Europe" is an increasingly popular idea on the right, but it isn't realistic. Europe has 10x the GDP of Russia, 5x the population, and 3x greater military spending. In case of war Europe can increase its military spending by ~5x, but Russia can't since it's already at 10% of GDP. Russia is simply not a great power.

items.title:
I realize I need a new wireless keyboard and mouse combo for one of my side projects

I go on Amazon...
items.content:
I realize I need a new wireless keyboard and mouse combo for one of my side projects

I go on Amazon to check out a cheap combo that I had purchased before for a different project

It turns out they have the expedited shipping for it

One hour later I am holding the said combo

Capitalism is absolutely amazing.

items.title: I got to train with Khabib Nurmagomedov (@TeamKhabib) yesterday. This was an honor of a lifetime for...
items.content:
I got to train with Khabib Nurmagomedov (@TeamKhabib) yesterday. This was an honor of a lifetime for me. He's a great fighter & leader and a great human being.

From a grappling perspective, I don't think I've ever experienced this much top pressure in my life.

I'll post the footage of the training in a few days. And also we'll do a long podcast (and dub it in multiple languages).

In general, it was an incredible experience to train with the team and get to know many of the fighters from Dagestan. All are great people.
items.author: @lexfridman
items.summary: Lex Fridman discusses training with Khabib Nurmagomedov.
items.summary_html: Lex Fridman discusses training with Khabib Nurmagomedov.
items.content_html:
I got to train with Khabib Nurmagomedov (@TeamKhabib) yesterday. This was an honor of a lifetime for me. He's a great fighter & leader and a great human being.

From a grappling perspective, I don't think I've ever experienced this much top pressure in my life.

I'll post the footage of the training in a few days. And also we'll do a long podcast (and dub it in multiple languages).

In general, it was an incredible experience to train with the team and get to know many of the fighters from Dagestan. All are great people.

items.title: Watched the first episode of the fifth season of Stranger Things right after finishing to rewatch th...
items.content:
Watched the first episode of the fifth season of Stranger Things right after finishing to rewatch the previous four and felt cringy most of the time.

I'm not an expert in video production, but I can feel the way they built this episode is different from all episodes of the previous four seasons.

I have a feeling that the previous four were mostly real, shot in real environments, in real nature, and this new one feels like it was entirely made on a green screen (or blue screen, whatever they are using these days).

The intro with young Will looked just plain wrong. If the young Eleven from the fourth season looked like a dwarf version of the older one, Will in the fifth just looks like a different dead child actor.

Plot and dialogues also feel wrong and made up. Characters don't seem to be the same people we have been knowing for 9 years.

Does anyone have the same feeling? What do you think they have done differently?

items.summary: Burkov reviews Stranger Things Season 5, criticizing production quality.

items.title:
Some say the world will end in fire,
Some say in ice.
From what I‚Äôve tasted of desire
I hold with th...
items.content:
Some say the world will end in fire,
Some say in ice.
From what I‚Äôve tasted of desire
I hold with those who favor fire.
But if it had to perish twice,
I think I know enough of hate
To say that for destruction ice
Is also great
And would suffice.

~ Robert Frost
items.author: @tunguz
items.summary: Tunguz shares Robert Frost poem 'Fire and Ice'
items.summary_html: Tunguz shares Robert Frost poem 'Fire and Ice'
items.content_html:
Some say the world will end in fire,

Some say in ice.

From what I‚Äôve tasted of desire

I hold with those who favor fire.

But if it had to perish twice,

I think I know enough of hate

To say that for destruction ice

Is also great

And would suffice.

~ Robert Frost
